metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: There is also a " for-each " loop, which is used exclusively to loop through elements in an array (or other data sets):
content.html: There is also a "for-each" loop, which is used exclusively to loop through elements in an array (or other data sets):

content.code_html:
for (type variableName : arrayName) {
  // code block to be executed
}

content.text: The following example outputs all elements in the cars array, using a " for-each " loop:
content.html: The following example outputs all elements in the cars array, using a "for-each" loop:

content.code_html:
String[] cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
for (String i : cars) {
  System.out.println(i);
}

content.text: Note: Don't worry if you don't understand the example above. You will learn more about Arrays in the Java Arrays chapter .
content.html: Note: Don't worry if you don't understand the example above. You will learn more about Arrays in the Java Arrays chapter.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What is the output of the following code? int[] myNumbers = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}; for (int i : myNumbers) { System.out.println(i); }
content.html:
What is the output of the following code?
int[] myNumbers = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
for (int i : myNumbers) {
  System.out.println(i);
}
